forest65@rainforest.title: Soft Ground
forest65@rainforest.description:
You are squelching through a muddy part of the forest.  The river is close
by to the south and it is making its presence felt.  With every step your feet
sink into the mud and water covers your shoes.  This land of trees and water
is beginning to get you down.

forest79@rainforest.title: Tannin Pool
forest79@rainforest.description:
You are standing by the side of a large pool of water, though it may be a
channel and therefore part of the river.  The water is still and clear, though
you can see nothing moving in it.  It is the colour of tea but does not look
drinkable.

forest19@rainforest.title: Bank Of The River Malazon
forest19@rainforest.description:
You are on the bank of a smallish river.  It is quiet and flows slowly, and
you could cross here if you wished.  Above you spider monkeys chatter in the
canopy, feeding on figs and any other fruit that they can find.

forest74@rainforest.title: Ungulates' Trail
forest74@rainforest.description:
You are in a dense part of the forest, where thick bushes bar your way in
every direction but to the east, where a trail of sorts leads deeper into the
jungle.  What kind of animals have made it, you can only guess.

mount28@rainforest.title: Icy Rock Face
mount28@rainforest.description:
You are halfway up the rock face, clinging on for dear life, though your
hands are getting exceedingly cold in the process.  Some of your footholds are
worryingly slippery owing to a thin but lethal coating of black ice.  You can
continue up or down from here.

forest145@rainforest.title: Edge Of The Pool
forest145@rainforest.description:
A large pool, separated from the main body of the river by a small bank
about three feet wide, blocks your path.  It is impossible to tell how deep it
is, as the water in it is almost black with dark mud.

forest33@rainforest.title: In The Canopy
forest33@rainforest.description:
You are up in the canopy.  Looking up, you can see the sky, but in every
other direction all you can see are leaves.  The tree you are in is one of
the particularly competitive species which tower up into the sky, its top high
above the canopy.  You could probably climb it if you had a mind to.  Otherwise
you can descend to the ground or move across the branches into another tree.

forest36@rainforest.title: In The Canopy
forest36@rainforest.description:
You are up in the canopy.  Looking up, you can see the sky, but in every
other direction all you can see are leaves.  The tree you are in is one of
the particularly competitive species which tower up into the sky, its top high
above the canopy.  You could probably climb it if you had a mind to.  Otherwise
you can descend to the ground or move across the branches into another tree.

forest42@rainforest.title: Topmost Branches
forest42@rainforest.description:
You are in the uppermost branches of one of the taller trees in the
rainforest, looking out over the vast spread of the canopy which stretches out
to the horizon in all directions but to the west, where tall mountains and
snow-capped volcanos rise up from the forests to touch the clouds.  The next
tree is too far away for you to reach, so the only way from here is down.

forest67@rainforest.title: Leeches Galore
forest67@rainforest.description:
You have come upon the kind of terrain leeches love best.  And in this
humid jungle the leeches are of staggering sizes.  However the large ones are
easy to cope with; it is the small ones that get inside your clothes that you
are most concerned about.  You continually have to stop and pluck them from
your body, and that is not always easy... their suction-cup mouths grip you
with surprising strength.

forest127@rainforest.title: Stone God
forest127@rainforest.description:
You are in a deep part of the forest where only a little light reaches the
ground.  An enormous stone statue stands here, partially crumbled but still
imposing.  It appears to be a god of some kind, and its terrible eyes are
intact and manage to convey a sense of awesome power.  Whether the race who
carved it is still flourishing somewhere in the heart of the rainforest, you
have no idea.

river22@rainforest.title: Southern Estuarine Waters
river22@rainforest.description:
You are in the southern part of the estuary.  The distant tree-lined shore
seems so far away and the hours you spent trekking through the jungle are
little more than a dim memory.  The open sea lies to the east.

forest38@rainforest.title: In The Canopy
forest38@rainforest.description:
You are up in the canopy.  Here on the spreading branches many plants make
their home which you would normally think of as belonging on the ground.
Orchids and other epiphytes make use of their hosts in order to catch the sun's
rays which are too rare on the dim forest floor below.  You can descend to the
ground or move across the branches into another tree.

forest131@rainforest.title: Beneath The Understorey
forest131@rainforest.description:
The understorey here is particularly impressive, since the canopy is
inexplicably almost bare.  Tall palms are making the most of the extra light
and their fronds wave about gently in the slight breeze which reaches them from
above.

forest66@rainforest.title: Land Of The Butterflies
forest66@rainforest.description:
In this drier part of the forest many species of butterfly are swarming.
Some settle on your face and arms and lick off your sweat with their long
probosces, hungry for salt.  Some of the others are huge, almost a foot across,
but those tend to stay away from you.  Their wingbeats are distinctly audible.

mount23@rainforest.title: On The Moraine
mount23@rainforest.description:
You are following the moraine along the side of the glacier.  At this point
the glacier runs fairly straight for a while and the chances of meeting a
crevasse are reduced, should you wish to cross here.  Otherwise you can head
east or west along the moraine.

forest81@rainforest.title: Where The Hummingbirds Hum
forest81@rainforest.description:
This part of the forest has a quiet, ethereal quality.  You are on high
ground within sight of the river, where tall plants abound with deep flowers
whose nectar only hummingbirds can reach.  Several of those tiny birds are
hovering around here, their humming increasing in pitch every time they move.
You can go east and west from here.

mount43@rainforest.title: Winding Path
mount43@rainforest.description:
You are on a long and winding path by which animals and explorers may climb
from the rainforest up into the mountains, or descend from the mountains into
the trees.  Whichever way you choose to go, it is a long haul.

forest144@rainforest.title: Thick Rainforest
forest144@rainforest.description:
You are in a very crowded part of the forest.  Your movements are very
limited but you think you can probably go east for a little way before you are
forced to stop.  The only other exit is back to the south.

forest29@rainforest.title: Deep In The Rainforest
forest29@rainforest.description:
You are wandering through the heart of the rainforest.  The density of the
trees makes it impossible to continue in a straight line and you wonder whether
you might be going round in circles.  There are exits in all directions.

forest25@rainforest.title: Deep In The Rainforest
forest25@rainforest.description:
You are wandering through the heart of the rainforest.  The density of the
trees makes it impossible to continue in a straight line and you wonder whether
you might be going round in circles.  There are exits in all directions.

pataniku@rainforest.name: Pataniku
pataniku@rainforest.description: Pataniku the Indian grins at you with yellow teeth.

llama@rainforest.name: Llama
llama@rainforest.description: A llama is here, protected from the cold by her thick fur.

scarlet@rainforest.name: Scarlet
scarlet@rainforest.description: A scarlet macaw flies to and from his nest in the cliff.

kinkajou@rainforest.name: Kinkajou
kinkajou@rainforest.description: A kinkajou, a monkey-like carnivore, feeds from his perch in the trees.

leech7@rainforest.name: Leech7
leech7@rainforest.description: A big hungry leech eagerly begins to feast on your blood.

swordbill@rainforest.name: Swordbill
swordbill@rainforest.description: A swordbill hummingbird flits from flower to flower.

leech2@rainforest.name: Leech2
leech2@rainforest.description: A big hungry leech eagerly begins to feast on your blood.

jaguar@rainforest.name: Jaguar
jaguar@rainforest.examine: He is the biggest cat in the forest and you are to be his next meal!
jaguar@rainforest.description: There is a terrifying roar and a yellow blur, and a jaguar is upon you!

curassow@rainforest.name: Curassow
curassow@rainforest.description: A chunky flightless bird called a curassow is pecking scraps from the ground.

leech5@rainforest.name: Leech5
leech5@rainforest.description: A big hungry leech eagerly begins to feast on your blood.

tricops@rainforest.name: Tricops
tricops@rainforest.description: Tricops, a frog-eating bat, hangs upside down from a branch.

nakorehu@rainforest.name: Nakorehu
nakorehu@rainforest.description: Nakorehu glares at you in annoyance.

anaconda@rainforest.name: Anaconda
anaconda@rainforest.description: A giant anaconda glides towards you over the wet ground.

howler@rainforest.name: Howler
howler@rainforest.description: A howler monkey emits deafening cries from its woody perch.

mogani@rainforest.name: Mogani
mogani@rainforest.description: Mogani the Indian is here hunting monkeys.

tamandua@rainforest.name: Tamandua
tamandua@rainforest.description: Tamandua the anteater rakes the nest with his huge claws.

tapir@rainforest.name: Tapir
tapir@rainforest.description: A tapir trundles by, apparently unaware of your presence.

piranha2@rainforest.name: Piranha2
piranha2@rainforest.description: A vicious piranha attacks your legs.

tanacu@rainforest.name: Tanacu
tanacu@rainforest.description: Tanacu looks up in surprise as you enter his hut.

alpaca@rainforest.name: Alpaca
alpaca@rainforest.description: An alpaca is here, feeding on the hardy plants by the side of the path.

agouti@rainforest.name: Agouti
agouti@rainforest.description: An agouti is digging here for roots and tubers.

caiman@rainforest.name: Caiman
caiman@rainforest.examine: It is very large and could hurt you a lot!
caiman@rainforest.description: A black caiman is annoyed that you have interrupted his bask.

iguana@rainforest.name: Iguana
iguana@rainforest.description: A large green iguana is taking a nap on one of the nearby branches.

horse@rainforest.name: Horse
horse@rainforest.description: A wild horse tosses his mane proudly and whinnies as you arrive.

capuchin@rainforest.name: Capuchin
capuchin@rainforest.description: A black capuchin monkey leaps about here among the branches.

piranha7@rainforest.name: Piranha7
piranha7@rainforest.description: A vicious piranha attacks your legs.

ants@rainforest.name: Ants
ants@rainforest.examine: One or two have noticed your presence and are coming to investigate.
ants@rainforest.description: There are ants all over here!

manatee@rainforest.name: Manatee
manatee@rainforest.description: A mournful-looking manatee surfaces just next to you.

duck@rainforest.name: Duck
duck@rainforest.description: A torrent duck is plucking stonefly larvae from one of the rocks here.

hoatzin@rainforest.name: Hoatzin
hoatzin@rainforest.description: A hoatzin, an evil-smelling and primitive bird, is clinging to the branches by  means of claws on its wings.

peccary@rainforest.name: Peccary
peccary@rainforest.description: A pig-like collared peccary eats fungi from the forest floor.

leech@rainforest.name: Leech
leech@rainforest.description: A truly elephantine leech fastens itself securely to your leg.

egret@rainforest.name: Egret
egret@rainforest.description: A great egret, majestic and white, is standing by the water's edge.

parakeet@rainforest.name: Parakeet
parakeet@rainforest.description: A beautiful but noisy parakeet flaps about your head annoyingly.

bear@rainforest.name: Bear
bear@rainforest.description: A spectacled bear is taking a nap here.

piranha5@rainforest.name: Piranha5
piranha5@rainforest.description: A vicious piranha attacks your legs.

condor@rainforest.name: Condor
condor@rainforest.examine: With a wingspan of nearly ten feet and a host of sharp claws he fears nothing.
condor@rainforest.description: A condor has chosen this spot to make his nest.

uacari@rainforest.name: Uacari
uacari@rainforest.examine: His bright red face is a peculiar sight.
uacari@rainforest.description: A red uacari monkey looks at you glumly.

owl@rainforest.name: Owl
owl@rainforest.description: A horned owl scans the ground for mouse oppossums.

ocelot@rainforest.name: Ocelot
ocelot@rainforest.examine: He is a medium-sized member of the cat family.
ocelot@rainforest.description: An ocelot watches you keenly from the branches.

tortoise@rainforest.name: Tortoise
tortoise@rainforest.description: A big tortoise leaps to the attack!  In an hour he will be upon you!

harpy@rainforest.name: Harpy
harpy@rainforest.description: A harpy eagle reaches for you with massive talons.

piranha3@rainforest.name: Piranha3
piranha3@rainforest.description: A vicious piranha attacks your legs.

spider@rainforest.name: Spider
spider@rainforest.description: A spider monkey chatters at you from an adjacent branch.

turtle@rainforest.name: Turtle
turtle@rainforest.description: A turtle swims about in the shallow water.

green@rainforest.name: Green
green@rainforest.description: A green macaw mobs you, agitated by your presence.

latuka@rainforest.name: Latuka
latuka@rainforest.description: Latuka the Indian is gathering herbs here.

bat@rainforest.name: Bat
bat@rainforest.description: An evil blackbat vampire wants to taste your blood!

chinchilla@rainforest.name: Chinchilla
chinchilla@rainforest.examine: He is very small but his thick fur gives him ample protection against the cold.
chinchilla@rainforest.description: A chinchilla scurries about on the rocks by your feet.

axape@rainforest.name: Axape
axape@rainforest.description: Axape the Indian chief leaps at you with murder on his mind.

explorer@rainforest.name: Explorer
explorer@rainforest.examine: His clothes are in tatters and his beard reaches his waist.
explorer@rainforest.description: A wild-eyed and insane explorer suddenly leaps up, reaching for your throat.

pirarucu@rainforest.name: Pirarucu
pirarucu@rainforest.description: A pirarucu, an enormous freshwater fish, is swimming by the side of the raft.

caracara@rainforest.name: Caracara
caracara@rainforest.description: A caracara flies close by you, mobbing you.  Maybe you are near his nest.

biguli@rainforest.name: Biguli
biguli@rainforest.description: Biguli is a well-built Indian who doesn't like trespassers.

stag@rainforest.name: Stag
stag@rainforest.description: A large stag is drinking from the river here.

vulture@rainforest.name: Vulture
vulture@rainforest.description: A yellow-headed vulture swoops down on you from above.

potona@rainforest.name: Potona
potona@rainforest.description: Potona, the matriarch of the village, threatens you with a brandished pot.

nineband@rainforest.name: Nineband
nineband@rainforest.description: A nine-banded armadillo is scuffling about here looking for food.

piranha6@rainforest.name: Piranha6
piranha6@rainforest.description: A vicious piranha attacks your legs.

guanaco@rainforest.name: Guanaco
guanaco@rainforest.examine: He is a member of the camel family and has a long graceful neck.
guanaco@rainforest.description: A sure-footed guanaco plucks at the sparse greenery.

leech4@rainforest.name: Leech4
leech4@rainforest.description: A big hungry leech eagerly begins to feast on your blood.

puma@rainforest.name: Puma
puma@rainforest.description: A puma snarls at you and prepares to spring, his hair bristling.

leech3@rainforest.name: Leech3
leech3@rainforest.description: A big hungry leech eagerly begins to feast on your blood.

umbrellabird@rainforest.name: Umbrellabird
umbrellabird@rainforest.description: The umbrella bird is the ugliest bird you have ever seen.

pudu@rainforest.name: Pudu
pudu@rainforest.description: Pudu the dwarf deer is feeding on succulent plants here.

piranha1@rainforest.name: Piranha1
piranha1@rainforest.description: A vicious piranha attacks your legs.

toucan@rainforest.name: Toucan
toucan@rainforest.description: A huge-beaked toucan squawks at you unattractively.

leech1@rainforest.name: Leech1
leech1@rainforest.description: A big hungry leech eagerly begins to feast on your blood.

corixi@rainforest.name: Corixi
corixi@rainforest.description: Corixi puts down an unfinished pot and orders you out of his hut.

capybara@rainforest.name: Capybara
capybara@rainforest.description: A capybara, the world's largest rodent, trots around on stumpy legs.

beguriga@rainforest.name: Beguriga
beguriga@rainforest.description: Beguriga the medicine-man shouts at you with obvious wrath.

tegu@rainforest.name: Tegu
tegu@rainforest.description: A three-foot tegu lizard snaps its powerful jaws at you in warning.

king@rainforest.name: King
king@rainforest.description: A brightly-coloured king vulture swoops down on you from above!

piranha4@rainforest.name: Piranha4
piranha4@rainforest.description: A vicious piranha attacks your legs.

dolphin@rainforest.name: Dolphin
dolphin@rainforest.description: A freshwater dolphin leaps playfully in the water beside your raft.

squirrel@rainforest.name: Squirrel
squirrel@rainforest.description: A squirrel monkey dangles from the branches using its prehensile tail.

karitu@rainforest.name: Karitu
karitu@rainforest.description: Karitu the Indian is wandering through the forest here.

sloth@rainforest.name: Sloth
sloth@rainforest.description: A three-toed sloth climbs ponderously up one of the trees.

leech6@rainforest.name: Leech6
leech6@rainforest.description: A big hungry leech eagerly begins to feast on your blood.
